biblStruct.note: The article analyses two fragments from the work of Bardaiṣan which the Neoplatonic philosopher Porphyry preserves in his De Styge and De abstinentia. Focusing especially on the longer piece from De Styge, it explores both Bardaiṣan’s treatment of India and Porphyry’s reception of it as contributions to the philosophical and literary Greek-speaking discourse of the Imperial period and shows how both authors are deeply rooted in Greek paideia and its conventions.
